Now that I think about it I know the reason why I'm not seeing this
stack t=
race output -- I'm using a custom XML result formatter which I
derived from=
 Ant's XMLJUnitResultFormatter which is gobbling the
exception stack trace =
info (it only leaves the meaningful messages I
add into the thrown exceptio=
ns in my code). I needed to shorten the
report output for failures and so I=
 created this custom result
formatter, but for errors I really do want to s=
ee the exception stack
trace. So I need to modify my result formatter to ha=
ndle error
messages differently than failure messages, or just stop using m=
y own
result formatter until I work out these errors.


--James



--- In j=
unit@yahoogroups.com, "james_adams" <james_adams@...> wrote:
>
> I'm runnin=
g a JUnit test via Ant's <junit> task. It completes with an
> error, but I =
have yet to determine what the error is. I have tried
> using the <record> =
Ant task with a debug loglevel to create a log
> file, and I've tried using=
 the <junitreport> task to create an HTML
> report of the test run, neither=
 of which has resulted in anything
> which gives me a clue as to what the e=
rror is. Can someone suggest
> another approach?
> 
> Thanks in advance for=
 any suggestions.
>

> --James
